title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Every week, Lucas makes 4 pieces of chocolate candy for each of his students on Monday. He made 40 pieces of chocolate candy last Monday. This upcoming Monday, 3 of Lucas' students will not be coming to class. How many pieces of chocolate candy will Lucas make for his class on Monday?

Lucas has 40/4 = <<40/4=10>>10 students.
He has 10 - 3 = <<10-3=7>>7 students this week.
Therefore, Lucas will make 4 x 7 = <<4*7=28>>28 pieces of chocolate candy. Answer: \boxed{28}.


Question: Every week, Lucas makes 4 pieces of chocolate candy for each of his students on Monday. He made 40 pieces of chocolate candy last Monday. This upcoming Monday, 3 of Lucas' students will not be coming to class. How many pieces of chocolate candy will Lucas make for his class on Monday?

Lucas has 40/4 = <<40/4=10>>10 students.
Lucas will make candy for 10-3 = <<10-3=7>>7 students on Monday.
Lucas will make 4*7 = <<4*7=28>>28 pieces of chocolate candy. Answer: \boxed{28}.


Question: Leo has to write a 400-word story for his literature class. 10 words fit on each line of his notebook and 20 lines fit on each page. Lucas has filled one and a half pages. How many words does he have left to write?

One page has 10 * 20 = <<10*20=200>>200 words.
He has filled in 1.5 * 200 = <<1.5*200=300>>300 words.
He has 400 - 300 = <<400-300=100>>100 words left to write. Answer: \boxed{100}.


Question: Leo has to write a 400-word story for his literature class. 10 words fit on each line of his notebook and 20 lines fit on each page. Lucas has filled one and a half pages. How many words does he have left to write?

One and a half pages is 1.5 * 20 = <<1.5*20=30>>30 lines.
Therefore, Lucas has already written 30 *10 = <<30*10=300>>300 words.
Thus, Lucas has 400 - 300 = <<400-300=100>>100 words left to write. Answer: \boxed{100}.


Question: Leo has to write a 400-word story for his literature class. 10 words fit on each line of his notebook and 20 lines fit on each page. Lucas has filled one and a half pages. How many words does he have left to write?

In one page, Lucas can write 10 words/line x 20 lines/page = <<10*20=200>>200 words.
So, Lucas has filled a total of 1.5 x 200 words/page = <<1.5*200=300>>300 words.
Therefore, Leo has 400 words - 300 words = <<400-300=100>>100 words left to write. Answer: \boxed{100}.


Question: Every week, Lucas makes 4 pieces of chocolate candy for each of his students on Monday. He made 40 pieces of chocolate candy last Monday. This upcoming Monday, 3 of Lucas' students will not be coming to class. How many pieces of chocolate candy will Lucas make for his class on Monday?
text:
Lucas has 40/4 = <<40/4=10>>10 students.
He has 10 - 3 = <<10-3=7>>7 students this week.
Therefore, Lucas will make 4 x 7 = <<4*7=28>>28 pieces of chocolate candy. Answer: \boxed{28}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: John assembles computers and sells prebuilt computers as a business. The parts for the computer cost $800.  He sells the computers for 1.4 times the value of the components.  He manages to build 60 computers a month.  He has to pay $5000 a month in rent and another $3000 in non-rent extra expenses a month.  How much profit does he make a month?

He makes the $800 parts cost * 1.4 markup = $<<800*1.4=1120>>1120 for each computer
So he makes a profit of $1120 price - $800 cost = $<<1120-800=320>>320
That means his total monthly profit is $320 profit per computer * 60 computers = $<<320*60=19200>>19200
The total cost of the non-rent expenses is $5000 rent + $3000 expenses = $<<5000+3000=8000>>8000
So his total profit before non-rent expenses is $19200 profit - $8000 non-rent expenses = $<<19200-8000=11200>>11,200. Answer: \boxed{11,200}.


Question: John runs a telethon to raise money.  For the first 12 hours, he generates $5000 per hour.  The remaining 14 hours, he generates 20% more per hour.  How much total money does he make?

He earns 12*5000=$<<12*5000=60000>>60,000 for the first 12 hours
He gets an increase of 5000*.2=$<<5000*.2=1000>>1000 per hour
So he gets 5000+1000=$<<5000+1000=6000>>6000 per hour
That means for the remaining 14 hours, he gets 14*6000=$<<14*6000=84000>>84,000
So his total income is 84,000+60,000=$<<84000+60000=144000>>144,000. Answer: \boxed{144000}.


Question: John runs a website that gets 30000 visits a month, for a normal 30 day month.  He gets $.01 per visit.  How much does he make per day?

He makes 30000*.01=$<<30000*.01=300>>300 per month
So he makes $300/30=$<<300/30=10>>10 per day. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: John runs a website that gets 30000 visits a month, for a normal 30 day month.  He gets $.01 per visit.  How much does he make per day?

He gets 30000*.01=$<<30000*.01=300>>300 per month
So he makes 300/30=$<<300/30=10>>10 a day. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: John runs a website that gets 30000 visits a month, for a normal 30 day month.  He gets $.01 per visit.  How much does he make per day?

He gets 30000*.01=$<<30000*.01=300>>300 per month
So he makes 300/30=$<<300/30=10>>10 per day. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: John assembles computers and sells prebuilt computers as a business. The parts for the computer cost $800.  He sells the computers for 1.4 times the value of the components.  He manages to build 60 computers a month.  He has to pay $5000 a month in rent and another $3000 in non-rent extra expenses a month.  How much profit does he make a month?
text:
He makes the $800 parts cost * 1.4 markup = $<<800*1.4=1120>>1120 for each computer
So he makes a profit of $1120 price - $800 cost = $<<1120-800=320>>320
That means his total monthly profit is $320 profit per computer * 60 computers = $<<320*60=19200>>19200
The total cost of the non-rent expenses is $5000 rent + $3000 expenses = $<<5000+3000=8000>>8000
So his total profit before non-rent expenses is $19200 profit - $8000 non-rent expenses = $<<19200-8000=11200>>11,200. Answer: \boxed{11,200}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Robbie weighs 100 pounds. Patty was 4.5 times as heavy as Robbie, but she has since lost 235 pounds by working out. How many more pounds does Patty weigh than Robbie now?

Patty now weighs 100 * 4.5 = <<100*4.5=450>>450 pounds.
Patty now weighs 450 - 235 = <<450-235=215>>215 pounds.
Patty weighs 215 - 100 = <<215-100=115>>115 more pounds than Robbie. Answer: \boxed{115}.

Patty weighed 450 pounds before working out because 4.5 x 100 = <<4.5*100=450>>450
Patty weighs 215 pounds now because 450 - 235 = <<450-235=215>>215
Patty weighs 115 more pounds than Robbie because 215 - 100 = <<215-100=115>>115. Answer: \boxed{115}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jason is tired of the neighborhood animals raiding his trash. He pepper-sprays some raccoons and 6 times as many squirrels. If he pepper-sprays 84 animals total, how many raccoons does he pepper-spray?

Let r be the number of raccoons Jason pepper-sprays
Jason sprays 6*r squirrels
Jason sprays r + 6*r = 84 animals
7*r = 84
r = <<12=12>>12 raccoons. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Jason is tired of the neighborhood animals raiding his trash. He pepper-sprays some raccoons and 6 times as many squirrels. If he pepper-sprays 84 animals total, how many raccoons does he pepper-spray?

Let R be the number of raccoons Jason pepper-sprays and S be the number of squirrels. We know that R + S = 84 and S = 6R.
Substituting the second equation into the first equation, we get R + 6R = 84
Combining like terms, we get 7R = 84
Dividing both sides by 7, we get R = 12. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Jason is tired of the neighborhood animals raiding his trash. He pepper-sprays some raccoons and 6 times as many squirrels. If he pepper-sprays 84 animals total, how many raccoons does he pepper-spray?

Let s be the number of squirrels Jason pepper-sprays and r be the number of raccoons. We know that s = 6r and s + r = 84.
Substituting the first equation into the second equation, we get 6r + r = 84
Combining like terms, we get 7r = 84
Dividing both sides by 7, we get r = 12. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Jason is climbing a telephone pole next to a tree his friend Matt is climbing. Matt can climb 6 feet/minute and Jason can climb 12 feet per minute. After 7 minutes, how much higher will Jason be than Matt?

After 7 minutes, Matt will have climbed 7 * 6 = <<7*6=42>>42 feet.
After 7 minutes, Jason will have climbed 7 * 12 = <<7*12=84>>84 feet.
Jason will be 84 - 42 = <<84-42=42>>42 feet higher than Matt. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Jason is climbing a telephone pole next to a tree his friend Matt is climbing. Matt can climb 6 feet/minute and Jason can climb 12 feet per minute. After 7 minutes, how much higher will Jason be than Matt?

After 7 minutes, Matt will have climbed 7 minutes * 6 feet/minute = <<7*6=42>>42 feet.
And after 7 minutes, Jason will have climbed 7 minutes * 12 feet/minute = <<7*12=84>>84 feet.
So after 7 minutes, Jason will be 84 - 42 = <<84-42=42>>42 feet higher than Matt. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Jason is tired of the neighborhood animals raiding his trash. He pepper-sprays some raccoons and 6 times as many squirrels. If he pepper-sprays 84 animals total, how many raccoons does he pepper-spray?
text: Let r be the number of raccoons Jason pepper-sprays. We know that he pepper-sprays 6 times as many squirrels, so the number of squirrels is 6r. In total, he pepper-sprays r + 6r = 7r animals. We are given that he pepper-sprays a total of 84 animals, so we can set up the equation 7r = 84. Dividing both sides by 7, we find that r = 12. Therefore, Jason pepper-sprays 12 raccoons. Answer: \boxed{12}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A chef has served 58 adults, 35 fewer children than the number of adults, and twice as many seniors as children. What is the total number of guests served?

The chef has served 58 adults
The number of children is 58-35 = <<58-35=23>>23
The number of seniors is 23*2 = <<23*2=46>>46
The total number of guests served is 58+23+46 = <<58+23+46=127>>127 guests. Answer: \boxed{127}.


Question: A chef has served 58 adults, 35 fewer children than the number of adults, and twice as many seniors as children. What is the total number of guests served?

The number of children served is 58 adults - 35 children = <<58-35=23>>23 children.
The number of seniors served is 23 children x 2 seniors/child = <<23*2=46>>46 seniors
The total number of guests served is 58 adults + 23 children + 46 seniors = <<58+23+46=127>>127 guests. Answer: \boxed{127}.


Question: A chef has served 58 adults, 35 fewer children than the number of adults, and twice as many seniors as children. What is the total number of guests served?

The chef has served 58 adults.
The number of children is 35 less than the number of adults, which means there are 58 - 35 = <<58-35=23>>23 children.
The number of seniors is twice the number of children, which means there are 23 x 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 seniors.
The total number of guests served is 58 adults + 23 children + 46 seniors = <<58+23+46=127>>127 guests. Answer: \boxed{127}.


Question: A chef has served 58 adults, 35 fewer children than the number of adults, and twice as many seniors as children. What is the total number of guests served?

The number of children is 58 - 35 = <<58-35=23>>23 children.
There are 23 x 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 seniors.
So, the chef served a total of 58 + 23 + 46 = <<58+23+46=127>>127 guests. Answer: \boxed{127}.


Question: A chef has served 58 adults, 35 fewer children than the number of adults, and twice as many seniors as children. What is the total number of guests served?

If the chef has served 58 adults, and 35 fewer children than the number of adults, there are 58-35=<<58-35=23>>23 children present.
The number of seniors at the event, twice the number of children, is 2*23=<<2*23=46>>46
The total number of guests served by the chef is 58+23+46=<<58+23+46=127>>127. Answer: \boxed{127}.


Question: A chef has served 58 adults, 35 fewer children than the number of adults, and twice as many seniors as children. What is the total number of guests served?
text:
The chef has served 58 adults. 
Since there are 35 fewer children than the number of adults, there are 58 - 35 = <<58-35=23>>23 children. 
And since there are twice as many seniors as children, there are 23 * 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 seniors. 
Therefore, the total number of guests served is 58 + 23 + 46 = <<58+23+46=127>>127 guests. Answer: \boxed{127}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Carrie is making punch. She adds 6 12-oz cans of Mountain Dew, 28 oz of ice, and a 40 oz bottle of fruit juice. How many 10 oz servings of punch does Carrie have?

First find the total volume of the Mountain Dew: 6 cans * 12 oz/can = <<6*12=72>>72 oz
Then add that amount to the volume of the other ingredients: 72 oz + 28 oz + 40 oz = <<72+28+40=140>>140 oz
Then divide the total volume by the volume per serving to find the number of servings: 140 oz / 10 oz/serving = <<140/10=14>>14 servings. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Carrie is making punch. She adds 6 12-oz cans of Mountain Dew, 28 oz of ice, and a 40 oz bottle of fruit juice. How many 10 oz servings of punch does Carrie have?

The Mountain Dew is 6 cans * 12 oz/can = <<6*12=72>>72 oz.
The fruit juice is 40 oz.
The punch is 72 oz + 28 oz + 40 oz = <<72+28+40=140>>140 oz.
Thus, Carrie has 140 oz / 10 oz/serving = <<140/10=14>>14 servings of punch. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Carrie is making punch. She adds 6 12-oz cans of Mountain Dew, 28 oz of ice, and a 40 oz bottle of fruit juice. How many 10 oz servings of punch does Carrie have?

Carrie adds 6 cans * 12 oz = <<6*12=72>>72 oz of Mountain Dew.
She has a total of 72 oz + 28 oz + 40 oz = <<72+28+40=140>>140 oz of punch.
She has 140 oz / 10 oz = <<140/10=14>>14 servings of punch. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Carrie is making punch. She adds 6 12-oz cans of Mountain Dew, 28 oz of ice, and a 40 oz bottle of fruit juice. How many 10 oz servings of punch does Carrie have?

First find the total volume of the soda: 6 cans * 12 oz/can = <<6*12=72>>72 oz
Then add the volume of the ice and juice to find the total volume of the punch: 72 oz + 28 oz + 40 oz = <<72+28+40=140>>140 oz
Then divide the total volume of the punch by the volume of each serving to find the number of servings: 140 oz / 10 oz/serving = <<140/10=14>>14 servings. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Carrie is making punch. She adds 6 12-oz cans of Mountain Dew, 28 oz of ice, and a 40 oz bottle of fruit juice. How many 10 oz servings of punch does Carrie have?

Carrie has 6 cans of 12 oz Mountain Dew for a total of 6*12= <<6*12=72>>72 oz of Mountain Dew.
In addition to the 72 oz of Mountain Dew, Carrie adds 28 oz of ice and 40 oz of fruit juice for a total of 72+28+40=<<72+28+40=140>>140 oz of punch.
Since each serving is 10 oz, then Carrie has 140/10 =<<140/10=14>>14 servings. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Carrie is making punch. She adds 6 12-oz cans of Mountain Dew, 28 oz of ice, and a 40 oz bottle of fruit juice. How many 10 oz servings of punch does Carrie have?
text:
To find the total volume of the punch, we first need to find the volume of the Mountain Dew. Since Carrie adds 6 cans of Mountain Dew, and each can is 12 oz, the total volume of the Mountain Dew is 6 * 12 = 72 oz.
Next, we add the volume of the ice and the fruit juice. The ice has a volume of 28 oz and the fruit juice has a volume of 40 oz. Therefore, the total volume of the punch is 72 + 28 + 40 = 140 oz.
Finally, to find the number of 10 oz servings of punch, we divide the total volume of the punch by the volume per serving: 140 / 10 = 14. 
Answer: \boxed{14} servings of punch.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Nathan plays amateur baseball. He played for 3 hours for two weeks, every day. His friend Tobias played for 5 hours every day, but only for one week. How many hours did Nathan and Tobias play in total?

Nathan played for 3 hours/day * 7 days/week = <<3*7=21>>21 hours per week.
So in two weeks, Nathan played for 21 hours/week * 2 weeks = <<21*2=42>>42 hours.
Tobias played for 5 hours/day * 7 days = <<5*7=35>>35 hours in total.
Nathan and Tobias played a total of 42 hours + 35 hours = <<42+35=77>>77 hours. Answer: \boxed{77}.


Question: Nathan plays amateur baseball. He played for 3 hours for two weeks, every day. His friend Tobias played for 5 hours every day, but only for one week. How many hours did Nathan and Tobias play in total?

Nathan played a total of 3 hours/day * 7 days/week * 2 weeks = <<3*7*2=42>>42 hours.
Tobias played a total of 5 hours/day * 7 days/week * 1 week = <<5*7*1=35>>35 hours.
In total, they played 42 hours + 35 hours = <<42+35=77>>77 hours. Answer: \boxed{77}.


Question: Nathan plays amateur baseball. He played for 3 hours for two weeks, every day. His friend Tobias played for 5 hours every day, but only for one week. How many hours did Nathan and Tobias play in total?

Nathan played for 3 hours * 7 days = <<3*7=21>>21 hours in one week.
In total, he played for 21 hours * 2 weeks = <<21*2=42>>42 hours.
Tobias played for 5 hours * 7 days = <<5*7=35>>35 hours in one week.
In total, Tobias played for 35 hours * 1 week = <<35*1=35>>35 hours.
All together, Nathan and Tobias played for 42 hours + 35 hours = <<42+35=77>>77 hours. Answer: \boxed{77}.


Question: Nathan plays amateur baseball. He played for 3 hours for two weeks, every day. His friend Tobias played for 5 hours every day, but only for one week. How many hours did Nathan and Tobias play in total?

Nathan played a total of 3 hours/day x 7 days/week = <<3*7=21>>21 hours/week.
So for two weeks, Nathan played a total of 21 hours/week x 2 weeks = <<21*2=42>>42 hours.
Tobias played a total of 5 hours/day x 7 days/week = <<5*7=35>>35 hours/week.
So for one week, Tobias played a total of 35 hours.
Therefore, Nathan and Tobias played a total of 42 hours + 35 hours = <<42+35=77>>77 hours. Answer: \boxed{77}.


Question: Bret takes a 9 hour train ride to go to Boston.   He spends 2 hours reading a book, 1 hour to eat his dinner, and 3 hours watching movies on his computer.  How many hours does he have left to take a nap?

He spent 2+1+3=<<2+1+3=6>>6 hours on other activities.
Thus, Bret took a 9-6=<<9-6=3>>3 hour nap. Answer: \boxed{3}.


Question: Nathan plays amateur baseball. He played for 3 hours for two weeks, every day. His friend Tobias played for 5 hours every day, but only for one week. How many hours did Nathan and Tobias play in total?
text:
Nathan played a total of 3 hours/day * 7 days/week * 2 weeks = <<3*7*2=42>>42 hours.
Tobias played a total of 5 hours/day * 7 days/week * 1 week = <<5*7*1=35>>35 hours.
In total, they played 42 hours + 35 hours = <<42+35=77>>77 hours. Answer: \boxed{77}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A piece of wire 5 feet 4 inches long was divided into 4 equal parts. How long was each part in inches if 1 foot is equal to 12 inches?

The total length of the wire in inches is 5 x 12 + 4 = <<5*12+4=64>>64 inches.
Each part is 64/4 = <<64/4=16>>16 inches long. Answer: \boxed{16}.


Question: A piece of wire 5 feet 4 inches long was divided into 4 equal parts. How long was each part in inches if 1 foot is equal to 12 inches?

5 feet 4 inches is equal to 5 x 12 + 4 = <<5*12+4=64>>64 inches.
Each part is 64 / 4 = <<64/4=16>>16 inches long. Answer: \boxed{16}.


Question: A piece of wire 5 feet 4 inches long was divided into 4 equal parts. How long was each part in inches if 1 foot is equal to 12 inches?

The length of the wire is 5 feet + 4 inches = 5*12 + 4 = <<5*12+4=64>>64 inches.
Each part is 64 inches / 4 parts = <<64/4=16>>16 inches/part. Answer: \boxed{16}.


Question: A piece of wire 5 feet 4 inches long was divided into 4 equal parts. How long was each part in inches if 1 foot is equal to 12 inches?

The total length of the wire in inches is 5 x 12 + 4 = <<5*12+4=64>>64 inches.
Each part of the wire is 64 / 4 = <<64/4=16>>16 inches long. Answer: \boxed{16}.


Question: A piece of wire 5 feet 4 inches long was divided into 4 equal parts. How long was each part in inches if 1 foot is equal to 12 inches?

First, convert the total length of wire to inches: 5 feet * 12 inches/foot + 4 inches = <<5*12+4=64>>64 inches
Then divide that length by 4 to find how long each part is: 64 inches / 4 = <<64/4=16>>16 inches/part. Answer: \boxed{16}.


Question: A piece of wire 5 feet 4 inches long was divided into 4 equal parts. How long was each part in inches if 1 foot is equal to 12 inches?
text:
The total length of the wire is 5 feet 4 inches, which is equal to 5 x 12 + 4 = <<5*12+4=64>>64 inches.
To find the length of each part, divide the total length by the number of parts: 64 inches / 4 parts = <<64/4=16>>16 inches/part. Answer: \boxed{16}.

title:

Question: Rob has some baseball cards, and a few are doubles. One third of Rob's cards are doubles, and Jess has 5 times as many doubles as Rob. If Jess has 40 doubles baseball cards, how many baseball cards does Rob have?

Rob has 40/5 =<<40/5=8>>8 baseball cards.
Rob has 8 * 3 = <<8*3=24>>24 baseball cards. Answer: \boxed{24}.

If Jess has 40 doubles baseball cards, and five times as many doubles baseball cards as Rob, Rob has 40/5= <<40/5=8>>8 double baseball cards.
Since one third of Rob's cards are doubles, this means that Rob has 8/(1/3)= <<8/(1/3)=24>>24 baseball cards. Answer: \boxed{24}.
